channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus World News: Live Updates
item.description: Celebrations on the 75th anniversary of the end of World War II were muted. The E.U. ambassador to China was criticized for allowing an opinion article to be redacted. In India, an operation has started to repatriate citizens.
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers, foreground, at a Victory Day commemoration at the Soviet War Memorial in Tiergarten park in Berlin on Friday.

item.title: Kenyans Held For Weeks in Quarantine Were Told to Pay to Get Out
item.description: Hundreds in the East African nation were put in quarantine for breaking curfew or not wearing masks. That, some said, was just the start of their ordeal.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A government designated quarantine facility in Nairobi, Kenya, in early April.

item.title: A Philosopher-Banker Who’s Shaking Up a Nation
item.description: Steven Coutinho had long wanted to help Suriname, his homeland, overcome its colonial past. A huge financial scandal gave him his chance.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Central Bank of Suriname. The nation’s government admitted having used more than $200 million in banking reserves to import basic foodstuffs.

item.title: Hidden Toll: Mexico Ignores Wave of Coronavirus Deaths in Capital
item.description: More than three times as many people may have died from Covid-19 in Mexico City than federal statistics show, according to a Times analysis.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sterilizing the chapel at the Xilotepec Cemetery in the Xochimilco neighborhood of Mexico City on Thursday.

item.title: An Incursion Into Venezuela, Straight Out of Hollywood
item.description: The operation to overthrow the president failed miserably, and eight rebels were killed. But a former Green Beret who was not on the mission has emerged as the central character.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Frances Robles
item.category: United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Members of a Venezuelan special forces unit standing guard after a failed incursion on Sunday.

item.title: Coronavirus Reopenings Raise Ethical Dilemmas
item.description: As countries move ahead despite limited knowledge, whole societies are becoming unwitting test subjects of what works — and what they’re willing to give up.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuting in Milan, Italy, on Monday after lockdown restrictions were eased.

item.title: Google Sibling Abandons Ambitious City of the Future in Toronto
item.description: In scrapping the project, the company cited the economic upheaval caused by the coronavirus pandemic, but critics say it was a loser from the start and a failure in “surveillance capitalism.”
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: What had been the future site of the Google Sidewalk Labs development in Toronto.

item.title: Eager to Corral the Coronavirus, U.K. Tests a Disputed Tracing App
item.description: The British government’s tool to track infected people puts it at odds with Apple and Google on privacy.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cyclists keeping distance in London last week. The government is moving forward with an app designed to track coronavirus infections.

item.title: As Local Health Systems Buckle, Russia’s Oligarchs Take Charge
item.description: The growing role of business tycoons in the fight against the coronavirus highlights the weaknesses of the state apparatus built by President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: NorNickel employees preparing to disinfect Norilsk Airport this week. The company and its owner, oligarch Vladimir O. Potanin, have played a large role in fighting the coronavirus pandemic in the city of Norilsk, Russia.

item.title: Coronavirus Killing Black Britons at Twice the Rate of Whites
item.description: That gap grows to four times when class and health differences aren’t considered. South Asians have also been dying disproportionately.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Munuse Nabi, who died of covid-19, was buried at a cemetery in London last month.

item.title: Pandemic Forces Poland to Delay Presidential Election
item.description: Europe’s first presidential election since the outbreak of coronavirus will not take place in Poland on Sunday, despite a chaotic push by the governing party to press ahead with an all-postal ballot.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Berendt and Marc Santora
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters in Warsaw objecting to the Law and Justice Party’s plans for a vote-by-mail election.

item.title: Israeli Army’s Idea Lab Aims at a New Target: Saving Lives
item.description: The country has engaged defense contractors, doctors, engineers, scientists — and most of the senses — in its battle against the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: The control room at the coronavirus critical care department of the Sheba Medical Center in Ramat Gan, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: Naikon, Group Tied to China's Military, Deploys Debilitating New Cyberattack Tool
item.description: An Israeli security company said the hacking software, called Aria-body, had been deployed against governments and state-owned companies in Australia and Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Steven Lee Myers
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, seen on a screen at the World Internet Conference in Wuzhen, China, in October.

item.title: Gas Leak in India at LG Factory Kills 11 and Sickens Hundreds
item.description: Residents in eastern India woke up in the middle of the night surrounded by a cloud of styrene vapor. Many couldn’t breathe.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Suhasini Raj, Kai Schultz and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: The authorities evacuated thousands of people from the area around the LG chemical plant in Visakhapatnam, India, on Thursday morning.

item.title: As India Reopens, Deadly Accidents Break Out
item.description: A group of laborers trying to get home were run over by a train a day after a disaster at a plastics factory.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Suhasini Raj and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Carrying the body of a victim after a train ran over migrant workers sleeping on a track in the western Indian state of Maharashtra on Friday.

item.title: Coronavirus, Ahmaud Arbery, Michael Flynn: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Outside a bar in Vilnius, Lithuania.

item.title: April Jobs Report Shows Record Unemployment Rate: Live News Tracker
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Britain, Antibodies, Bundesliga: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Shannon
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Schools reopened in Denmark with children required to social-distance themselves.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The White House rejected C.D.C. guidelines for reopening, and states ignored White House criteria.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Moderna Gets OK to Start Larger Trial for a Coronavirus Vaccine
item.description: The company announced that the Food and Drug Administration had cleared its application to proceed to a clinical trial involving about 600 people.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:description: Moderna Therapeutics in Cambridge, Mass., in March. It is one of the first biotech companies to begin human trials of an experimental coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: After Recovery From the Coronavirus, Most People Carry Antibodies
item.description: A new study adds to evidence of immunity among those who have already been exposed to the pathogen.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Taking blood for antibody testing at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan last month.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: India gas leak, Britain’s economy, George Pell: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
item.media:description: People affected by a chemical gas leak in Visakhapatnam, India, were carried out on a truck to an ambulance on Thursday.

item.title: Turkey Charges Pilots and Others Over Carlos Ghosn’s Escape
item.description: Prosecutors in Istanbul have completed an indictment against seven people, formally charging four pilots and an airline official of illegally smuggling a migrant.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Former Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn at a press conference in Beirut, Lebanon, in January. Prosecutors have completed an indictment against seven people in Mr. Ghosn’s escape from Japan to Lebanon.

item.title: Afghan War Casualty Report: May 2020
item.description: At least 42 pro-government forces and four civilians have been killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
item.dc:creator: Fahim Abed
item.media:description: Afghan security officials check people at a check point in Helmand province, Afghanistan, 04 May 2020. Although clashes between the Afghan security forces and the Taliban fighters continued in rural areas, attacks in cities had come down to almost nil.

item.title: U.S. Military Killed 132 Civilians in Wars Last Year, Pentagon Says
item.description: The tally has changed little since the previous year’s report, which put the total at 120 civilians killed. Civilian deaths in Afghanistan again eclipsed those in Syria and Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An American military vehicle at Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan last year.

item.title: Cardinal George Pell Knew of Clergy Sex Abuse, Australian Report Finds
item.description: The cardinal, whose sexual abuse conviction was overturned last month, knew decades ago that priests had victimized children but failed to take action, a government inquiry concluded.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: A Royal Commission said it was difficult to believe claims by Cardinal George Pell, center, that his superiors in the church had deceived him.

item.title: Coronavirus, President Trump, India: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired generating station in Sidney, Mont.

item.title: Travel From New York City Seeded Wave of U.S. Outbreaks
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak in New York City became the primary source of infections around the United States, researchers have found.
item.dc:creator: Benedict Carey and James Glanz

item.title: Filipino Musicians Drive Hong Kong’s Music Scene, but Gigs Have Dried Up
item.description: Battered by the one-two punch of protests and a pandemic, Hong Kong’s music venues have mostly gone silent. No one has felt the pinch more than singers, drummers and guitarists from the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jezrael Lucero plays piano at the Grand Hyatt in Wan Chai, Hong Kong, last week.

item.title: Global Tracker: U.K., India, Russia
item.description: Poland has postponed its presidential election amid debate over how to conduct voting safely. In India, a deadly gas leak may have resulted from a rush to reopen a chemical plant.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police guards outside St. Thomas’ Hospital in London last month.

item.title: Stocks Rise, With Tech Index Now Up for 2020
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: President Trump with Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, during a meeting on small businesses at the White House last month.

item.title: Recession, Germany, U.S. Hunger: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Shannon
item.media:description: Factories like this steel plant in Milan have resumed production, but Italy’s economy is expected to shrink by over 9 percent this year.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: People who have recovered from Covid-19 describe what it really feels like to endure the disease.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Parents Nervously Return to Work in Italy. Children Are Still at Home.
item.description: Millions of Italians went back to the office this week. But with schools and day care closed and grandparents at risk, many feel the coronavirus has upended their futures as working parents.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chiara Monti and her youngest child, 3. Families in Italy say the government has not done enough to take into account the unique challenges facing working parents in the pandemic.

item.title: Iraq Chooses New Prime Minister, an Ex-Intelligence Chief Backed by U.S.
item.description: With the selection of Mustafa al-Kadhimi, Iraq has its first real government in more than five months. He will confront an array of daunting problems.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi, of Iraq, delivering his first televised address after his nomination in April.

item.title: Germany’s Reopening Offers Hope for a Semblance of Normal Life
item.description: Europe’s largest democracy is now confident enough to lift most restrictions on businesses and schools.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A clothing store in Berlin. Some businesses and schools reopened in Germany on Wednesday.

item.title: Israeli High Court Lets Netanyahu Form Government, Despite Indictments
item.description: The court ruling clears the last major obstacle to Mr. Netanyahu’s claiming a record fifth term as Israel’s leader.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during an event in Kiryat Arba, an Israeli settlement in the West Bank, in February.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: India lockdown, Vladimir Putin, black holes: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: People waiting to enter a vegetable and fruit market in New Delhi on Wednesday.

item.title: As U.K. Deaths Mount, Political Terrain Gets Trickier for Boris Johnson
item.description: Facing off against the new Labour leader, Keir Starmer, in an eerily quiet Parliament, the prime minister seemed uncharacteristically defensive.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain leaving his residence at 10 Downing Street in London for Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Did a Mutation Turbocharge the Coronavirus? Not Likely, Scientists Say
item.description: A preliminary report posted online claimed that a mutation had made the virus more transmissible. Geneticists say the evidence isn’t there.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, via Reuters
item.media:description: A colored scanning electron micrograph of a dying cell infected with the coronavirus, with viral particles in red.

item.title: Kenya and Somalia to Jointly Investigate Cargo Plane Crash
item.description: The Kenyan-registered private plane was carrying humanitarian supplies to use in the fight against the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The site of a plane crash in the town of Bardale, Somalia, on Monday. The private cargo plane belonging to African Express Airways was carrying supplies for combatting the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Are Negotiating a Prisoner Release Despite Rising Tensions
item.description: The talks come even as the Trump administration intensifies its ‘maximum pressure’ strategy of sanctions against Iran and threatens to shoot Iranian gunboats in the Persian Gulf.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Michael R. White in Mashhad, Iran, in mid-March. Negotiations aim to exchange Mr. White, who has been held in Iran for nearly two years, with an Iranian-American doctor.

item.title: Riyaz Naikoo: Top Kashmiri Militant Killed by Indian Troops
item.description: Over years of fighting, Riyaz Ahmad Naikoo recruited scores of young Kashmiris in an armed quest for independence from India. His death has set off a fresh wave of unrest.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir, Kai Schultz and Iqbal Kirmani
item.media:description: Indian Army soldiers in the Pulwama district on Wednesday, where a senior leader in a militant group was shot dead.

item.title: Coronavirus Puts Captive Orangutans’ Return to the Wild on Hold
item.description: If one ape in the forest is infected, a whole population could be wiped out, experts say. So orangutans in Indonesia’s rehabilitation centers are staying where they are.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: A Sumatran orangutan after it was released back into the wild in Aceh, Indonesia, in February.

item.title: As India Loosens Its Strict Lockdown, Coronavirus Deaths Jump Sharply
item.description: The streets have suddenly come alive, especially at night, in many areas where social distancing is impossible.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Kai Schultz
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Indian policeman using a thermometer to check a commuter entering New Delhi from the neighboring state of Uttar Pradesh last week.

item.title: Coronavirus, White House Task Force, U.S. Senate: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Erdogan Faces His Biggest Test of the Pandemic: The Economy
item.description: Some are hoping that the coronavirus achieves what some of the president’s advisers have failed to do: persuade Mr. Erdogan to reverse his authoritarian grip over fiscal policy in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Municipality employees working on a water line in Istanbul during a three-day curfew to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s investment in development projects has left him open to criticism that he has placed the economy ahead of lives.

item.title: U.S. Businesses Take Steps to Reopen
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: The largest U.S. airlines are averaging just 17 passengers on domestic flights and 29 on international flights, an airline executive said in prepared testimony for a Senate hearing.

item.title: Britain’s Johnson Faces Virus Critics, but Israel’s Netanyahu Comes Out on Top
item.description: It was a grim day for the E.U., whose economy is expected to shrink 7.4 percent, and Vladimir Putin, whose approval ratings have plummeted. But Shanghai Disneyland is coming back.
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during his last campaign. He’ll be sworn in next week.

item.title: Coronavirus, France, Duterte: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Residents of Saint-Mande, near Paris, applauded healthcare workers on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Some children are developing a mysterious illness that appears to be linked to the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Ji Chaozhu, Interpreter for China During Nixon’s Trip, Dies at 90
item.description: With his flawless English, he sometimes translated for both American and Chinese officials, making him the “indispensable man.”
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Ji Chaozhu, center right, stood by Zhou Enlai’s side as he greeted President Nixon during the historic 1972 visit to China.

item.title: Young Leader Vowed Change in El Salvador but Wields Same Heavy Hand
item.description: Elected as a transformative leader who would propel the country forward, Nayib Bukele is now reminding critics of the country’s past autocrats, with his reliance on the military.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Security forces in El Salvador last month detaining a man who had gone out to buy groceries for violating quarantine.

item.title: India Repatriation, Duterte, France: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
item.media:description: Volunteers distributing meals to migrant workers at a distance in Dubai, where there is a reliance on the labor of millions of foreigners.

item.title: Herd Immunity, or Big 2nd Wave? Israel Antibody Testing Hopes to Find Out
item.description: Blood tests of 100,000 Israelis will try to assess exposure to Covid-19 on a nationwide scale.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Monday, Israel announced that citizens could leave their homes after a 40-day lockdown, but many aspects of economic and social life remain curtailed.

item.title: Bana Ali, Who Championed Basketball in Somalia, Dies at 54
item.description: Mr. Ali, who had the novel coronavirus, dedicated his own time and finances to promoting basketball and sports among Somali youth.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Bana Ali was Somalia’s main promoter of organized basketball, donating money and serving on several bodies devoted to the sport.

item.title: Coronavirus May Have Been In France a Month Before Previously Thought
item.description: A sample taken on Dec. 27 from a French patient with pneumonia has tested positive for coronavirus, nearly a month before the disease was first officially acknowledged to have emerged in France.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds on the grass near the Louvre on March 15. The next day, the French government ordered its lockdown.

item.title: A ‘Breakdown of Trust’: Pandemic Corrodes Church-State Ties in Russia
item.description: Even as the monasteries of the Orthodox Church are besieged by the coronavirus, apocalyptic-minded priests balk at state restrictions on public worship.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Patriarch Kirill, in the white headdress, leader of the Russian Orthodox Church, at a procession in Moscow last month. Experts say his reluctance to enforce orders against church gatherings has led to an explosion of coronavirus cases in monasteries and convents.

item.title: Irish Return an Old Favor, Helping Native Americans Battling the Virus
item.description: In 1847 the Choctaw people sent $170 to help during the potato famine. Irish donors are citing that gesture as they help two tribes during the Covid-19 pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin and Mihir Zaveri
item.media:description: The Kindred Spirits Choctaw Monument art installation in Midleton, Ireland, commemorating the Choctaw donation during the potato famine.

item.title: ABS-CBN, a Leading Broadcaster in the Philippines and Target of Duterte's Ire, Signs Off
item.description: ABS-CBN has closely documented President Rodrigo Duterte’s brutal war on drugs that has left thousands of people dead. Such coverage has made it a target of the administration.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte is seen on a monitor in the newsroom of an ABS-CBN News bureau in Manila’s northern suburb of Quezon City.

item.title: 'Murder Hornets' Both a Lethal Threat and a Tasty Treat in Japan
item.description: Long before the insects found their way to American shores, some Japanese prized them for their numbing crunch and the venomous buzz they add to liquor.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:description: Asian giant hornets from Japan in a display case at the Washington State Department of Agriculture.
